trial_identification.studytitle: A single-centre, randomized comparsion of the Efficacy and Safety of Intramuscular Olanzapine and Haloperidol in Treating Acutely Agitated patients in Emergency Department
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A single-centre, randomized comparsion of the Efficacy and Safety of Intramuscular Olanzapine and Haloperidol in Treating Acutely Agitated patients in Emergency Department

conditions.healthcondition: Sedation for the acutely agitated patients

interventions.interventions: Patients are randomized to either olanzapine or haloperidol groups. The study aim is to compare the time for sedation of acutely agitated patients in the olanzapine group (new treatment) with haloperidol group (traditional treatment). The duration of intervention is about 30 minutes after single dose of study drug. The dose of olanzapine and haloperidol are both intramuscularly 10mg. The estimated study period will be approximately one year and the sample size is approx 140 in each study group i.e. 280 subjects in total.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured from the time of administration of the study drug till the sedation scale (modified Thomas Combativeness scale) to 3 i.e. no agitation and no supervision required and time

primaryOutcome.outcome: Time to arousal defined as if the patient awakens to verbal commands, is able to count backwards from 10 to 1 and is able to follow simple commands
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured from the time of administration of the study drugs

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Any adverse events of drugs, that occurs during the intervention/study period.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Acute agitation that required chemical restraint.
